urn:contentItem:5VRY-XDT1-JCR4-X2NC-00000-00Rénover le capitalisme avec le libéralisme2019-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:58ZLexisNexisARTICLERégulation défaillanteRénover le capitalisme avec le libéralismeERIC LE BOUCHER

CHRONIQUE - En France, l'opinion publique est persuadée que les libéraux sont forcément favorables au capitalisme. Mais être vraiment libéral, c'est favoriser la régulation contre les monopoles.

Trop de libéralisme ou pas assez ? Le débat est en France tranché, si l'on peut dire, depuis toujours, par les gènes du pays. Réponse : trop. Les profits sont extravagants, les rémunérations des patrons scandaleuses, les « gilets jaunes » sont malheureux, la planète est surexploitée, le marché a tout le pouvoir. L'Etat doit reprendre la main.

Cette renaissance des idées interventionnistes « de gauche » ne se voit pas dans la politique nationale, si on en croit les sondages, à cause du goût des partis pour la division. Mais elle s'observe ailleurs, dans les pays qui ont fait l'expérience de l'inanité populiste, comme la Grande-Bretagne et les Etats-Unis.

Partout, la gauche redécouvre une vision traditionnelle d'un Etat fort qui, pourtant, a depuis belle lurette montré ses limites. Le principe du « taxer et dépenser » revient dans les programmes. La remontée des vieilles recettes va, dans la bouche d'Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, dite « AOC », toute jeune démocrate brillamment élue à New York lors des « midterms » l'an passé, jusqu'à prôner l'usage sans limite de la planche à billets par le gouvernement pour financer les besoins sociaux et environnementaux. Elle s'appuie sur une certaine « MMT » (« modern monetary policy »), inventée il y a un siècle. Partie sur ces pistes d'avant-hier, la gauche n'ira pas loin.

Régulation défaillante

Autrement féconde est l'école qui explique la défaillance des Etats, non parce qu'ils sont à court d'argent mais parce qu'ils ont failli à installer une bonne régulation du marché. Le constat de départ est le même : les fruits du capitalisme sont captés par quelques-uns, les inégalités se sont creusées au point que les majorités des populations souffrent, les populistes prospèrent sur cet échec.

Lire aussi :

La lutte contre les monopoles est un combat pour la liberté (Gaspard Koenig)

La faute en revient à l'Etat, non parce qu'il est appauvri mais parce que, mauvais régulateur, il a laissé s'installer des monopoles. Le « pouvoir de marché » des grandes firmes s'est accru depuis vingt-cinq ans dans les deux tiers des secteurs aux Etats-Unis. La concentration du capital y est devenue historiquement élevée. En témoignent les profits record qui représentent 76 % du PIB outre-Atlantique, au plus haut depuis un demi-siècle, a calculé « The Economist » (17 novembre 2018). On peut vouloir taxer ces monopoles, l'Europe le fait avec les Gafa. La bonne solution est de les casser, de rétablir la concurrence, conformément à un libéralisme efficace.

Google, Facebook, Amazon devraient aujourd'hui subir le sort d'un Rockefeller - dont l'empire pétrolier Standard Oil fut démantelé en 1911. Mais ce n'est pas fait parce que les grandes firmes ont « capté » trop de force législative à Washington. L'Autorité de la concurrence a été modifiée, elle n'a plus de pouvoir sur la structure de l'offre (Facebook a pu acheter Instagram en 2012, puis WhatsApp en 2014), et ne peut intervenir que si elle prouve que le consommateur est lésé. L'est-il ? En proposant un livre proche de ceux que vous avez précédemment commandés ou un hôtel pour les vacances, Big Tech rend service au consommateur. Difficile de prouver qu'il est lésé.

Lire aussi :

Pourquoi les Etats-Unis doivent réguler les Gafa (Kenneth Rogoff)

Mais les libéraux n'ont pas dit leur dernier mot. Big Tech a dérapé. En vendant les données personnelles à des fins politiques (Cambridge Analytica). En laissant foisonner sur le Net des propos liberticides et en ne tenant jamais les promesses faites d'endosser la responsabilité de ce qui se diffuse et de limiter les haines et les fausses nouvelles. Le « ciblage » publicitaire est devenu « manipulation », glissant dans un« capitalisme de surveillance », selon Shoshana Zuboff (1), où les comportements sont normalisés par les « amis » sur les réseaux sociaux. L'arrivée de l'intelligence artificielle ne peut que renforcer cette modernité aliénante à la Orwell... à la différence près que le Big Brother est cette fois nous tous.

Et si « les données » devenaient le troisième facteur économique aux côtés du capital et du travail, comme le propose Eric Posner, professeur à Chicago(2) ? Chacun serait propriétaire de l'historique de son comportement (déplacement, achats, lectures...), il serait rémunéré par les plates-formes quand elles l'utilisent et chacun doit pouvoir à son gré récupérer ses data pour les « louer » mieux à une autre plate-forme.

Pour redonner confiance dans le capitalisme, faut-il ressortir les vieilles idées de gauche ou inventer, au travers des technologies, des approches neuves ? Pour s'enrichir, le débat politique devrait, en France, abandonner les pensées toutes faites sur la concurrence et le libéralisme.

(1) « The Age of Surveillance Capitalism », Shoshana Zuboff, PublicAffairs, 2019.

(2) « Radical Markets : Uprooting Capitalism and Democracy for a Just Society », Eric Posner et Glen Weyl.

urn:contentItem:5VRY-XDT1-JCR4-X2SR-00000-00Rénover le capitalisme avec le libéralisme2019-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:58ZLexisNexisCHRONIQUEPg. 12Rénover le capitalisme avec le libéralisme

(1) « The Age of Surveillance Capitalism », Shoshana Zuboff, PublicAffairs, 2019. (2) « Radical Markets : Uprooting Capitalism and Democracy for a Just Society », Eric Posner et Glen Weyl.

ERIC LE BOUCHER

En France, l'opinion publique est persuadée que les libéraux sont forcément favorables au capitalisme. Mais être vraiment libéral, c'est favoriser la régulation contre les monopoles.


Trop de libéralisme ou pas assez ? Le débat est en France tranché, si l'on peut dire, depuis toujours, par les gènes du pays. Réponse : trop. Les profits sont extravagants, les rémunérations des patrons scandaleuses, les « gilets jaunes » sont malheureux, la planète est surexploitée, le marché a tout le pouvoir. L'Etat doit reprendre la main.

Cette renaissance des idées interventionnistes « de gauche » ne se voit pas dans la politique nationale, si on en croit les sondages, à cause du goût des partis pour la division. Mais elle s'observe ailleurs, dans les pays qui ont fait l'expérience de l'inanité populiste, comme la Grande-Bretagne et les Etats-Unis.

Partout, la gauche redécouvre une vision traditionnelle d'un Etat fort qui, pourtant, a depuis belle lurette montré ses limites. Le principe du « taxer et dépenser » revient dans les programmes. La remontée des vieilles recettes va, dans la bouche d'Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, dite « AOC », toute jeune démocrate brillamment élue à New York lors des « midterms » l'an passé, jusqu'à prôner l'usage sans limite de la planche à billets par le gouvernement pour financer les besoins sociaux et environnementaux. Elle s'appuie sur une certaine « MMT » (« modern monetary policy »), inventée il y a un siècle. Partie sur ces pistes d'avant-hier, la gauche n'ira pas loin.

Autrement féconde est l'école qui explique la défaillance des Etats, non parce qu'ils sont à court d'argent mais parce qu'ils ont failli à installer une bonne régulation du marché. Le constat de départ est le même : les fruits du capitalisme sont captés par quelques-uns, les inégalités se sont creusées au point que les majorités des populations souffrent, les populistes prospèrent sur cet échec.

La faute en revient à l'Etat, non parce qu'il est appauvri mais parce que, mauvais régulateur, il a laissé s'installer des monopoles. Le « pouvoir de marché » des grandes firmes s'est accru depuis vingt-cinq ans dans les deux tiers des secteurs aux Etats-Unis. La concentration du capital y est devenue historiquement élevée. En témoignent les profits record qui représentent 76 % du PIB outre-Atlantique, au plus haut depuis un demi-siècle, a calculé « The Economist » (17 novembre 2018). On peut vouloir taxer ces monopoles, l'Europe le fait avec les Gafa. La bonne solution est de les casser, de rétablir la concurrence, conformément à un libéralisme efficace.

Google, Facebook, Amazon devraient aujourd'hui subir le sort d'un Rockefeller - dont l'empire pétrolier Standard Oil fut démantelé en 1911. Mais ce n'est pas fait parce que les grandes firmes ont « capté » trop de force législative à Washington. L'Autorité de la concurrence a été modifiée, elle n'a plus de pouvoir sur la structure de l'offre (Facebook a pu acheter Instagram en 2012, puis WhatsApp en 2014), et ne peut intervenir que si elle prouve que le consommateur est lésé. L'est-il ? En proposant un livre proche de ceux que vous avez précédemment commandés ou un hôtel pour les vacances, Big Tech rend service au consommateur. Difficile de prouver qu'il est lésé.

Mais les libéraux n'ont pas dit leur dernier mot. Big Tech a dérapé. En vendant les données personnelles à des fins politiques (Cambridge Analytica). En laissant foisonner sur le Net des propos liberticides et en ne tenant jamais les promesses faites d'endosser la responsabilité de ce qui se diffuse et de limiter les haines et les fausses nouvelles. Le « ciblage » publicitaire est devenu « manipulation », glissant dans un« capitalisme de surveillance », selon Shoshana Zuboff (1), où les comportements sont normalisés par les « amis » sur les réseaux sociaux. L'arrivée de l'intelligence artificielle ne peut que renforcer cette modernité aliénante à la Orwell... à la différence près que le Big Brother est cette fois nous tous.

Et si « les données » devenaient le troisième facteur économique aux côtés du capital et du travail, comme le propose Eric Posner, professeur à Chicago (2) ? Chacun serait propriétaire de l'historique de son comportement (déplacement, achats, lectures...), il serait rémunéré par les plates-formes quand elles l'utilisent et chacun doit pouvoir à son gré récupérer ses data pour les « louer » mieux à une autre plate-forme.

Pour redonner confiance dans le capitalisme, faut-il ressortir les vieilles idées de gauche ou inventer, au travers des technologies, des approches neuves ? Pour s'enrichir, le débat politique devrait, en France, abandonner les pensées toutes faites sur la concurrence et le libéralisme.

urn:contentItem:5J2R-B451-DY0W-44PG-00000-00Rent or Mortgage Payments Too Expensive for Over 40 Million American Families; iPhones Sold in Walmart; Share of GoPro Going Higher; Market's2014-06-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:58ZLexisNexisRent or Mortgage Payments Too Expensive for Over 40 Million American Families; iPhones Sold in Walmart; Share of GoPro Going Higher; Market'sLanhamFULL TEXT

MELISSA FRANCIS, Fox BUSINESS ANCHOR: The coming housing boom pegged to get this, America's young adults, never mind the fact that one in three still live with their parents and it is the biggest week for IPOs since 2006. For some big-time tech investors still aren't happy. Could this be a sign of the top? Buyer beware, the one word that sells $40 billion worth of food each year and means absolutely nothing.

And paying up for some will power. We'll introduce you to the company that will help you unplug for a price. Because even when they say it's not it is always about money. Economic realities hitting home for more than 40 million American families. A new study out of Harvard University finding that 35 percent of U.S. households can't afford their current living situation. With me now, "The Wall Street Journal's" Veronica Dagher, editor of "Power Trend Profits, Chris Versace and Dominick Tavella of Diversified Financial. Thanks to all of you for joining us. So, what that means is that their rent or their mortgage consumes 30 percent of their monthly income. I mean this is huge. This is 40 million Americans. For a lot of them it consumes 50 percent! Veronica, this is a disaster.

VERONICA DAGHER, Fox BUSINESS: It is a disaster especially because the more you spend on housing the less you have to spend on other things like consumer discretionary goods. And so that has larger effects to our economy. These people are spending so much on their rent they can't go be buying, you know, new cars or taking vacations. They just don't have the money.

FRANCIS: And a lot of the problems has to do with the fact that incomes aren't growing, right, Chris?

CHRIS VERSACE, POWERTREND PROFIST: Absolutely. I mean you look at all the jobs that we've seen created, but we look at the mix of those jobs, lower income jobs. So, there's not a lot of wage growth. We are seeing inflation across food and energy, and to your point, Veronica, disposable income is going to be tapped, so where are these people going to live?

FRANCIS: No, I mean among the other problems that creates when you look at the GDP print that we saw this week and just the big pullback, a lot of it had to do with consumer spending. You're not spending on discretionary goods if you have this much of your money going to your rent and mortgage, right?

DOMINICK TAVELLA, DIVERSIFIED FINANCIAL: Not only that. But it's the tax consequence what is happened in the first quarter. So, people paying much higher taxes than they were before. They are paying much higher in cost of living issues, even though the government says there is no cost of living. Cost of housing has gone through the roof. It really as depressed the average consumer what they can actually do out there.

FRANCIS: OK, more fallout from Barclays, over alleged dark pool fraud. Charlie Gasparino first reported New York's lawsuit against Barclay's right here on "MONEY." Now, they're getting the cold shoulder from several big name brokerage firms, including Deutsche Bank and the Royal Bank of Canada. Chris, this is an interesting one. Because it seems like dark pools, if you look at this, we may die their own death. If now people are afraid when they stay away from them. What do you think?

VERSACE: I think you're absolutely right on that. We are ultimately designed for, which was to allow large pools to be traded, you know, it's very anonymously, so people can move in and out. But where there is lot of smoke there is fire. The SEC is investigating. And all of a sudden what may have been once so safe may not be.

FRANCIS: Veronica.

VERONICA DAGHER, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": I think investors are going to be demanding more transparency in this case.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

DAGHER: They want to see what's going on. They're called dark pools for a reason.

FRANCIS: For a reason, right.

DAGHER: Yes.

FRANCIS: It is the opposite of transparency. That is the whole point.

DAGHER: That's right, yeah. And I think a lot of these firms that are stepping away from their connections to Barclays right now. You know, there is a PR component to this, too.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

DAGHER: Nobody wants to be associated with a firm that could be saying false things to investors.

FRANCIS: What is so appalling about this, if it is true, Dominick, you know, the charges that on one hand they were saying that they weren't allowing traders to have preference a step ahead of others at the very same time that they were doing exactly that within their dark pools. And really, I mean, once again, it's just like such a big knock on Wall Street.

TAVELLA: Yeah, two things - first this is not a small investor problem. This is really institutional. Traders were looking to do big block trades and not let the whole world know what they're doing. Having said that they need to have a credibility, a trust with the institution that they're doing it. That they're getting fair pricing. That trades are being done orderly and efficiently. And when that doesn't happen the trust gets cut.

FRANCIS: But it does have to do with the small investor because it's this idea that Wall Street is rigged. And there's more and more of these stories come out. It makes a little guy feel like why in the world should I even get involved and why should I invest? Meanwhile, I mean the stock market has this thing that has really gone up in this recovery. So, if you're on the sidelines because you're paranoid you really lost out

TAVELLA: If the small investor out there trading 100 shares of Facebook, this is not their world, OK? And whether they should or shouldn't be trading on .

FRANCIS: Nobody keeps them away from investing at all, Veronica.

DAGHER: It's the express issue, yeah. They're even more skeptical. And they don't even understand what a dark pool is. A lot of professionals don't understand what that is. So, it's just - it's more confusion and more skepticism.

FRANCIS: Yeah. All right, the federal government is set to auction off $17 million worth of bitcoin today. This is all courtesy of the shuttered online market silk road. The online sell is shrouded in secrecy, speaking of secrecy, and is attracting some financial power players. Veronica, I mean, this is an interesting one. If they just went ahead and put all this out on the open market, bitcoin, it would totally depress the price.

DAGHER: Yeah, it would sink the price. It's going to be interesting to see how the government handles this. You know, it's not like selling confiscated Chevys that they have got from drug bust.

(LAUGHTER)

DAGHER: So, how this plays out and how the investors, you know, I think there were investor lists, potential bidder lists released already. How that affects the bidding will be interesting to watch.

FRANCIS: Yeah, Chris, are you watching this one?

VERSACE: I'm watching it a little bit. I'm wondering why the government doesn't pull in like a currency trader or somebody in the know for dealing with this .

FRANCIS: I thought they were? They're not doing that?

VERSACE: You know, it sounds like they're doing it in-house. We know that they are not going to do it well. So, you know, how well can they leak this out? That's the big question.

TAVELLA: What is interesting that they confiscated these bitcoins from a criminal entity, right? The criminals are figuring out, bitcoin is the perfect tool to buy and sell assets without having trunk loads of 100- dollar bills. So, I think that's what's probably more interesting about this, is the government has figured it out, criminals figured it out, this is a perfect vehicle to trade value back and forth.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Absolutely. All right, iPhones hitting the bargain bin at Walmart. The retailer pricing Apple's smartphone for the - is rolling back prices to $29. I mean I can't believe this, the iPhone 5-c, $29. You have to buy a two year contract, but come on. Amazing.

DAGHER: Yeah, it's really cheap. But I think this is interesting because Walmart is only applying this deal for people who come into their stores. And I think this speaks to Walmart really needing to drive traffic. They're losing out on foot traffic. They're doing pretty good online, but they're trying to find a way to how to get people in these huge stores and that is a real issue. This might be a strategy to .

FRANCIS: Yeah, pretty smart thing for us.

VERSACE: Well, you know, two things. One I think it is smart for Walmart to bring people in to get them to shop and buy all these things. But also, I think it's smart for Apple. Remember the 5C was not a big volume device.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

VERSACE: It's a nice way for them to kind of flush out all the inventory in the channel potentially ahead of the iPhone 6.

FRANCIS: I think it's also interesting to me it means that, Apple has power to sell all across the price spectrum. Because it used to be the really high cost phone and you saw everybody, you know, couldn't afford it.

VERSACE: We don't know, necessarily know that it is Apple who is selling it for $29 through Walmart. Walmart could actually be buying the phone and subsidizing it to bring people in, kind of a loss leader.

TAVELLA: You know, Melissa, I will take the opposite of this one. Steve Jobs is going to be turning in his grave.

(LAUGHTER)

TAVELLA: But it's only with Apple cutting-edge technology, but this posh, this mystique, it was a Gucci bag, it was the Armani. Now, they are selling it on the discount bin in Walmart. I think it takes some of the luster away from Apple. I don't know. I think it takes the shine off.

FRANCIS: I think - interesting. All right. Life on Wall Street proving no piece of cake for Crumbs Bakery. The one time king of cupcakes will be dropped by the NASDAQ after falling by more than 80 percent in the past year. I mean I don't know if you guys notice this, they're on every corner right now. They have 70 stores. 22 of which were open in the last year. There is one on my block. There is another cupcake store within the next block. How many cupcake stores do we need, Chris?

VERSACE: Not that many apparently.

FRANCIS: Apparently, not that many.

VERSACE: And the thing is, you know, you can go almost anywhere now and get cupcakes. You can go to Starbucks and get cupcakes. You can go to .

FRANCIS: Big cupcakes.

VERSACE: Panera Bread and all this ...

TAVELLA: You can actually buy their cupcakes at BJ's. So, again, this idea, this mystique, this great store, you walk into, now they have kind of tarnished their brand. Competitors are coming.

FRANCIS: Isn't that a warning, so we have this huge IPO rush going on right now. I mean, you know, that it is - it's going to be the biggest week since 2006. I remember when Crumbs went public and I thought it was the most ridiculous thing. So, I'm like how can you be a public company when all you do is sell cupcakes? Is this the warning to Yo or all these other things? What do you think of it?

DAGHER: That is the point. Maybe not everyone should go public.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

DAGHER: Maybe it's not a good idea.

TAVELLA: So, let's look at Starbucks, right? Same theme. It's just coffee instead of a cupcake. They reinvented themselves, reinvented themselves, reinvented themselves and expanded intelligently. This company didn't single product. Lots of competition.

FRANCIS: I guess, although you - almost everybody needs a cup of coffee to get through the day. I don't need a cupcake.

(LAUGHTER)

TAVELLA: I probably need it, but .

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: All right, I'm going to lose my job.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Riding shotgun wedding. Uber expanding its reach into marital bliss, bringing free full service weddings to some lucky couples tomorrow. So I thought, you know, Uber is the king of this, we'll do something, you know, within an hour, bring it to you. They always have a gimmick on in order to promote themselves. But this one is really special. Because they say you just need to bring enough legal documents to get a marriage license with you, but they will provide the notary and a qualified officiate to handle the paperwork - ceremony, not to mention all the other accoutrements that go with it. Veronica.

DAGHER: Oh, man, I just got married.

(LAUGHTER)

DAGHER: And I wish that .

(LAUGHTER)

(CROSSTALK)

DAGHER: Actually, no.

FRANCIS: Will they do on demand divorce next?

(LAUGHTER)

TAVELLA: That might drive volume. FRANCIS: I don't know. I mean in Vegas it's easy to get married proving that you really shouldn't most of the time. Like they make it too easy. So, maybe these guys are doing the same thing.

VERSACE: You know, Melissa, I'm going to turn it back to you.

FRANCIS: OK.

VERSACE: Would you say that nothing says romance like Uber?

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: I don't know. Quickie wedding, it is very romantic.

TAVELLA: But Uber has done a lot of these kinds of gimmicks, right?

FRANCIS: It's funny.

TAVELLA: It's a hell of a lot cheaper than hiring a Park Avenue advertising firm.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

TAVELLA: Lots of PR. Get the name out there. It's fabulous. We laugh about it. It's good stuff.

FRANCIS: You guys were fantastic. Thank you so much.

Coming up the great band of China. Why Hillary Clinton's new book won't be hitting the bestseller's list in Shanghai anytime soon.

Plus, consumer sentiment is on the rise, but will feelings be enough to beat what lies beneath? "THE MONEY" hard truth coming up.

urn:contentItem:5J2R-B451-DY0W-44PW-00000-00Rent or Mortgage Payments Too Expensive for Over 40 Million American Families; iPhones Sold in Walmart; Share of GoPro Going Higher; Market's2014-06-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:58ZLexisNexisRent or Mortgage Payments Too Expensive for Over 40 Million American Families; iPhones Sold in Walmart; Share of GoPro Going Higher; Market'sLanhamFULL TEXT

MELISSA FRANCIS, Fox BUSINESS ANCHOR: The coming housing boom pegged to get this, America's young adults, never mind the fact that one in three still live with their parents and it is the biggest week for IPOs since 2006. For some big-time tech investors still aren't happy. Could this be a sign of the top? Buyer beware, the one word that sells $40 billion worth of food each year and means absolutely nothing.

And paying up for some will power. We'll introduce you to the company that will help you unplug for a price. Because even when they say it's not it is always about money. Economic realities hitting home for more than 40 million American families. A new study out of Harvard University finding that 35 percent of U.S. households can't afford their current living situation. With me now, "The Wall Street Journal's" Veronica Dagher, editor of "Power Trend Profits, Chris Versace and Dominick Tavella of Diversified Financial. Thanks to all of you for joining us. So, what that means is that their rent or their mortgage consumes 30 percent of their monthly income. I mean this is huge. This is 40 million Americans. For a lot of them it consumes 50 percent! Veronica, this is a disaster.

VERONICA DAGHER, Fox BUSINESS: It is a disaster especially because the more you spend on housing the less you have to spend on other things like consumer discretionary goods. And so that has larger effects to our economy. These people are spending so much on their rent they can't go be buying, you know, new cars or taking vacations. They just don't have the money.

FRANCIS: And a lot of the problems has to do with the fact that incomes aren't growing, right, Chris?

CHRIS VERSACE, POWERTREND PROFIST: Absolutely. I mean you look at all the jobs that we've seen created, but we look at the mix of those jobs, lower income jobs. So, there's not a lot of wage growth. We are seeing inflation across food and energy, and to your point, Veronica, disposable income is going to be tapped, so where are these people going to live?

FRANCIS: No, I mean among the other problems that creates when you look at the GDP print that we saw this week and just the big pullback, a lot of it had to do with consumer spending. You're not spending on discretionary goods if you have this much of your money going to your rent and mortgage, right?

DOMINICK TAVELLA, DIVERSIFIED FINANCIAL: Not only that. But it's the tax consequence what is happened in the first quarter. So, people paying much higher taxes than they were before. They are paying much higher in cost of living issues, even though the government says there is no cost of living. Cost of housing has gone through the roof. It really as depressed the average consumer what they can actually do out there.

FRANCIS: OK, more fallout from Barclays, over alleged dark pool fraud. Charlie Gasparino first reported New York's lawsuit against Barclay's right here on "MONEY." Now, they're getting the cold shoulder from several big name brokerage firms, including Deutsche Bank and the Royal Bank of Canada. Chris, this is an interesting one. Because it seems like dark pools, if you look at this, we may die their own death. If now people are afraid when they stay away from them. What do you think?

VERSACE: I think you're absolutely right on that. We are ultimately designed for, which was to allow large pools to be traded, you know, it's very anonymously, so people can move in and out. But where there is lot of smoke there is fire. The SEC is investigating. And all of a sudden what may have been once so safe may not be.

FRANCIS: Veronica.

VERONICA DAGHER, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": I think investors are going to be demanding more transparency in this case.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

DAGHER: They want to see what's going on. They're called dark pools for a reason.

FRANCIS: For a reason, right.

DAGHER: Yes.

FRANCIS: It is the opposite of transparency. That is the whole point.

DAGHER: That's right, yeah. And I think a lot of these firms that are stepping away from their connections to Barclays right now. You know, there is a PR component to this, too.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

DAGHER: Nobody wants to be associated with a firm that could be saying false things to investors.

FRANCIS: What is so appalling about this, if it is true, Dominick, you know, the charges that on one hand they were saying that they weren't allowing traders to have preference a step ahead of others at the very same time that they were doing exactly that within their dark pools. And really, I mean, once again, it's just like such a big knock on Wall Street.

TAVELLA: Yeah, two things - first this is not a small investor problem. This is really institutional. Traders were looking to do big block trades and not let the whole world know what they're doing. Having said that they need to have a credibility, a trust with the institution that they're doing it. That they're getting fair pricing. That trades are being done orderly and efficiently. And when that doesn't happen the trust gets cut.

FRANCIS: But it does have to do with the small investor because it's this idea that Wall Street is rigged. And there's more and more of these stories come out. It makes a little guy feel like why in the world should I even get involved and why should I invest? Meanwhile, I mean the stock market has this thing that has really gone up in this recovery. So, if you're on the sidelines because you're paranoid you really lost out

TAVELLA: If the small investor out there trading 100 shares of Facebook, this is not their world, OK? And whether they should or shouldn't be trading on .

FRANCIS: Nobody keeps them away from investing at all, Veronica.

DAGHER: It's the express issue, yeah. They're even more skeptical. And they don't even understand what a dark pool is. A lot of professionals don't understand what that is. So, it's just - it's more confusion and more skepticism.

FRANCIS: Yeah. All right, the federal government is set to auction off $17 million worth of bitcoin today. This is all courtesy of the shuttered online market silk road. The online sell is shrouded in secrecy, speaking of secrecy, and is attracting some financial power players. Veronica, I mean, this is an interesting one. If they just went ahead and put all this out on the open market, bitcoin, it would totally depress the price.

DAGHER: Yeah, it would sink the price. It's going to be interesting to see how the government handles this. You know, it's not like selling confiscated Chevys that they have got from drug bust.

(LAUGHTER)

DAGHER: So, how this plays out and how the investors, you know, I think there were investor lists, potential bidder lists released already. How that affects the bidding will be interesting to watch.

FRANCIS: Yeah, Chris, are you watching this one?

VERSACE: I'm watching it a little bit. I'm wondering why the government doesn't pull in like a currency trader or somebody in the know for dealing with this .

FRANCIS: I thought they were? They're not doing that?

VERSACE: You know, it sounds like they're doing it in-house. We know that they are not going to do it well. So, you know, how well can they leak this out? That's the big question.

TAVELLA: What is interesting that they confiscated these bitcoins from a criminal entity, right? The criminals are figuring out, bitcoin is the perfect tool to buy and sell assets without having trunk loads of 100- dollar bills. So, I think that's what's probably more interesting about this, is the government has figured it out, criminals figured it out, this is a perfect vehicle to trade value back and forth.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Absolutely. All right, iPhones hitting the bargain bin at Walmart. The retailer pricing Apple's smartphone for the - is rolling back prices to $29. I mean I can't believe this, the iPhone 5-c, $29. You have to buy a two year contract, but come on. Amazing.

DAGHER: Yeah, it's really cheap. But I think this is interesting because Walmart is only applying this deal for people who come into their stores. And I think this speaks to Walmart really needing to drive traffic. They're losing out on foot traffic. They're doing pretty good online, but they're trying to find a way to how to get people in these huge stores and that is a real issue. This might be a strategy to .

FRANCIS: Yeah, pretty smart thing for us.

VERSACE: Well, you know, two things. One I think it is smart for Walmart to bring people in to get them to shop and buy all these things. But also, I think it's smart for Apple. Remember the 5C was not a big volume device.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

VERSACE: It's a nice way for them to kind of flush out all the inventory in the channel potentially ahead of the iPhone 6.

FRANCIS: I think it's also interesting to me it means that, Apple has power to sell all across the price spectrum. Because it used to be the really high cost phone and you saw everybody, you know, couldn't afford it.

VERSACE: We don't know, necessarily know that it is Apple who is selling it for $29 through Walmart. Walmart could actually be buying the phone and subsidizing it to bring people in, kind of a loss leader.

TAVELLA: You know, Melissa, I will take the opposite of this one. Steve Jobs is going to be turning in his grave.

(LAUGHTER)

TAVELLA: But it's only with Apple cutting-edge technology, but this posh, this mystique, it was a Gucci bag, it was the Armani. Now, they are selling it on the discount bin in Walmart. I think it takes some of the luster away from Apple. I don't know. I think it takes the shine off.

FRANCIS: I think - interesting. All right. Life on Wall Street proving no piece of cake for Crumbs Bakery. The one time king of cupcakes will be dropped by the NASDAQ after falling by more than 80 percent in the past year. I mean I don't know if you guys notice this, they're on every corner right now. They have 70 stores. 22 of which were open in the last year. There is one on my block. There is another cupcake store within the next block. How many cupcake stores do we need, Chris?

VERSACE: Not that many apparently.

FRANCIS: Apparently, not that many.

VERSACE: And the thing is, you know, you can go almost anywhere now and get cupcakes. You can go to Starbucks and get cupcakes. You can go to .

FRANCIS: Big cupcakes.

VERSACE: Panera Bread and all this ...

TAVELLA: You can actually buy their cupcakes at BJ's. So, again, this idea, this mystique, this great store, you walk into, now they have kind of tarnished their brand. Competitors are coming.

FRANCIS: Isn't that a warning, so we have this huge IPO rush going on right now. I mean, you know, that it is - it's going to be the biggest week since 2006. I remember when Crumbs went public and I thought it was the most ridiculous thing. So, I'm like how can you be a public company when all you do is sell cupcakes? Is this the warning to Yo or all these other things? What do you think of it?

DAGHER: That is the point. Maybe not everyone should go public.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

DAGHER: Maybe it's not a good idea.

TAVELLA: So, let's look at Starbucks, right? Same theme. It's just coffee instead of a cupcake. They reinvented themselves, reinvented themselves, reinvented themselves and expanded intelligently. This company didn't single product. Lots of competition.

FRANCIS: I guess, although you - almost everybody needs a cup of coffee to get through the day. I don't need a cupcake.

(LAUGHTER)

TAVELLA: I probably need it, but .

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: All right, I'm going to lose my job.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Riding shotgun wedding. Uber expanding its reach into marital bliss, bringing free full service weddings to some lucky couples tomorrow. So I thought, you know, Uber is the king of this, we'll do something, you know, within an hour, bring it to you. They always have a gimmick on in order to promote themselves. But this one is really special. Because they say you just need to bring enough legal documents to get a marriage license with you, but they will provide the notary and a qualified officiate to handle the paperwork - ceremony, not to mention all the other accoutrements that go with it. Veronica.

DAGHER: Oh, man, I just got married.

(LAUGHTER)

DAGHER: And I wish that .

(LAUGHTER)

(CROSSTALK)

DAGHER: Actually, no.

FRANCIS: Will they do on demand divorce next?

(LAUGHTER)

TAVELLA: That might drive volume. FRANCIS: I don't know. I mean in Vegas it's easy to get married proving that you really shouldn't most of the time. Like they make it too easy. So, maybe these guys are doing the same thing.

VERSACE: You know, Melissa, I'm going to turn it back to you.

FRANCIS: OK.

VERSACE: Would you say that nothing says romance like Uber?

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: I don't know. Quickie wedding, it is very romantic.

TAVELLA: But Uber has done a lot of these kinds of gimmicks, right?

FRANCIS: It's funny.

TAVELLA: It's a hell of a lot cheaper than hiring a Park Avenue advertising firm.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

TAVELLA: Lots of PR. Get the name out there. It's fabulous. We laugh about it. It's good stuff.

FRANCIS: You guys were fantastic. Thank you so much.

Coming up the great band of China. Why Hillary Clinton's new book won't be hitting the bestseller's list in Shanghai anytime soon.

Plus, consumer sentiment is on the rise, but will feelings be enough to beat what lies beneath? "THE MONEY" hard truth coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Walking on sunshine. Consumer sentiment on the rise of beating street expectations today. Is this a ray of hope? Here now, Fox Business's Charlie Gasparino along with Veronica Dagher and former CBO director Doug Holtz-Eakin. Thanks so much for joining us. Doug, I'm going to let you go first.

DOUGH HOLTZ-EAKIN, FORMER CBO DIRECTOR: Thank you.

FRANCIS: Because you're on the road there. Consumer sentiment rising higher today. The consumer is what was missing from the GDP report. Consumer spending was very weak. That was one of the big reasons we saw the big contraction. Does this mean things are about to get better?

HOLTZ-EAKIN: I don't think so. If you look inside the numbers, they're happier about what is going on right now, but they are not more confident about the future. And if you look at the monthly data, we've seen in the past two months, the first two months of the second quarter, real declines in personal consumption expenditures. So, there is not a lot out there to suggest the households are going to pick up this economy and carry it.

FRANCIS: You know, Charlie, I always laugh when I see the consumer sentiment numbers. Because it's like asking people what they will do. It's not what they're actually doing.

CHARLIE GASPARINO, Fox BUSINESS: Right.

FRANCIS: I mean it's like how you are feeling.

GASPARINO: What they might do .

FRANCIS: Right.

GASPARINO: In the future maybe, possibly. I would just say this about - I think that negative GDP print was probably somewhat of an aberration. I don't think we're in a recession right now.

FRANCIS: It certainly make the recipe - you look like .

GASPARINO: It's not - it's not - I'm not going to say that's good. But you know, one thing about the Obama economy. We've seen this one before, where you have a blip up in GDP you have a blip up in consumer confidence. And then you get a blip down and then you really have very, very little economic growth.

FRANCIS: And it all nets out to just standing still. That's right.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: Charlie, may I point something out?

FRANCIS: Yeah.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: I mean here is the thing, Charlie. With the first quarter that we got, we'd have to go to 3.7 percent every quarter for the rest of the year, just to hit two percent for the year.

GASPARINO: OK.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: Never seen that in this presidency.

FRANCIS: And Veronica, I would say on the horizon, I mean, we have the specter of potential inflation. Have you heard James Bullard here on Fox Business earlier this week, he's already saying it's going to be hotter than we thought. Consumers as they go to the store every day, they certainly feel it being hotter every day. I mean is that a real threat, inflation?

DAGHER: Yeah, I think it is. Yes, you go to the grocery store now, things cost more than they did a couple of months ago. So, I think that is a real issue. And also, if you look at the personal spending numbers we got for May. If you adjust for inflation, those numbers actually went down. So, I think between that and people's fears about the economy, they are still seeing people - their neighbors without a job for a long time, people are underemployed. They're afraid to spend. So, we're going to see the savings rates continue to go up until we feel more secure. I don't know what that's going to take, though, to make them feel more secure.

FRANCIS: I mean Doug you are saying, you know, we would have to be above three percent for the rest of year in order to even out to something. What do you think is going to happen for the rest of the year?

HOLTZ-EAKIN: What this economy has done for years - is it's along the two percent. That's been the average consumption for growth, household spending growth, there's no evidence that they are going to change their behavior. They don't have the income or the sentiment to do it. Businesses are the wildcard.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: And if they somehow get some animal spirits and go with the big cap-ex expansion then we can get a good year, but I don't see that, Charlie.

GASPARINO: I agree with you. If you're talking about two percent growth and you have .

HOLTZ-EAKIN: I am.

GASPARINO: And you're talking about inflation in certain sectors where the Fed has to raise rates, we're heading for a recession. I mean Hillary Clinton runs for office. If she runs in 2015, 2016, she is very possible, that she runs in the middle of an economic downturn.

FRANCIS: Interesting. Meanwhile, you always make the point, Charlie, and you are right, the only one who's getting rich in this economy right now are people who are in the market. Because that is what all this Fed work has done, it's just stimulated the stock market. It's ironic that these policies out of Washington, all they've helped the one percent, who they say they hate. So, very interesting. Guys, thanks to all of you for joining us. From the U.S. to every corner of globe money is flying around the world today starting in Germany which has canceled the contract with Verizon over fears that the U.S. is spying on them. It all goes back to documents leaked by Edward Snowden, which revealed we had kind of an eavesdropping on calls made by Chancellor Angela Merkel. You remember that, right? Germans, they were not so amused by that, especially as the U.S. still refuses to agree with a no spy deal with the country. Verizon now bearing the brunt of that. It has been providing a communications network to the German government since 2010.

Over to Japan, which is now exporting square watermelons to grow throughout the globe. They curious, look at that are grown in boxes from a very young age. It sounds cruel. Which forces them into a cube-like shape. They weigh 13-pounds a apiece. Look at them.

(LAUGHTER)

FRANCIS: Well, I think about it, no, no, no. Now they are making way to fruit stand in Canada. They don't come cheap. One sold in Moscow last year, went for more than 800 bucks. Juicy profits indeed. Landing in China where Hillary Clinton is getting the cold shoulder by officials. Publishers there say they will not be purchasing the translation rights to her new book. Local agencies have banned the English language version from being imported. There are a few parts of book where she is somewhat critical of the Chinese government. You know, we kind of saw that one coming, right?

Crying wolves of Wall Street. The hottest week for IPOs in years and still not enough for some of the tech heavyweights. That picture is going to come back to haunt that guy. Plus, if you can't win them, beer them. One job hunter's clever case to seal the deal. We're raking in the money coming up next. See this of this guy.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Hold on tight. Shares of the venture camera maker GoPro powering higher in the second day of trading. Let's go to Ashley Webster on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. For more on this, when even higher today, Ashley.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, Fox BUSINESS: You know what they should do, Melissa. Scrap one of those GoPro cameras on the stock, of what you go up and down. Mostly up. But as we know, when - yesterday, the price was set at $24. It shot up yesterday and today. Look at this, it actually went above the $40 mark briefly before coming back down, still up 17percent. What else would you expect from this Adrenalin play on GoPro?

FRANCIS: Absolutely, still, Michael's not looking like a masterpiece, though, on its return to the market?

WEBSTER: No, a tale of two IPOs. Really, although that said, Michael's pricing it $17, debuting on the NASDAQ today, came out very slowly. Actually, went down below the IPO price. But it since inched its way up, and at least showing some positive signs, up 17, 1363 on the day. Up about three quarters of a percent. The arts and crafts. You know, by the way, I didn't realize, they also own the Aaron Brothers chain as well. So they go public finally. And up about 17, as I say, 14 cents above the share price that was listed. So, a slow but steady start I guess we'll call it. No GoPro.

FRANCIS: OK. All right, Ashley, thanks so much. So, the market wrapping up its biggest week for IPOs in eight years. Some big tech investors are not breaking out the champagne. Rather, they're crying about how hard it is to go public. Somewhere alone violin plays for them. Is this a sign of the top? Charlie is back with us, along with Scott Martin from United Advisors and Jonathan Hoenig from CapitalistPig Hedge Fund. They're both Fox News contributors. So, I mean it has been the week of endless IPOs. Still, you have Marc Andreessen up there saying, it comes across like I'm complaining about how hard it is to be public. Of course, the answer is, you just need to suck it up. I mean poor IPO guys getting out there and making a fortune. Jonathan, ridiculous?

JONATHAN HOENIG, CAPITALISTPIG HEDGE FUND: No, but we should be happy they're getting out there making a fortune, Melissa. We should be happy that deals are getting done and still being priced. I don't think this is the death of the IPO market at all, as you pointed out. It was an extremely busy week for IPOs. And you know, you'll the death comes when you see the IPOs starts coming public and just falling flat. It happened in 1999 .

FRANCIS: No, I know, but Scott . --

HOENIG: In 2000.

FRANCIS: I don't think it's so much the death of the IPO. I think it is more of a sign of the top. That you have a zillion coming out. It's the most in whatever we - you know, eight years. And then you have people complaining about how hard it is when here, everyone is doing it. How hard could it be? What do you think?

SCOTT MARTIN, UNITED ADVISORS: Well ..

FRANCIS: Everybody's got.

MARTIN: You're right, everybody is doing it. But here's the thing, Melissa. I mean Andreessen is complaining about the pricing I think more than anything. And he's talking about back in the '90s with Netscape and some of these other companies coming out at 2 billion valuation was kind of the status quo. Now you have got companies like Uber that are in - you know, $17 billion-dollar range. Even interest is somewhere between five and six billion. Here is the funny thing, right? GoPro is somewhere around 3 billion, but the stock is up gigantically, since it's IPO, because probably too cheap. So, it's more about pricing issue, but like Jonathan said I will never disagree with somebody in a seersucker suit, by the way.

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: That's the - stock, and that is why the prices are going up.

FRANCIS: Charlie.

GASPARINO: I'm not quite sure what Andreessen is complaining about. I mean is he complaining about the regulations?

FRANCIS: He's talking about for the young companies, you know, there is such a microscope on you. Every part of your business ends up being connected and end up being tied back to your self-pricing and morale.

GASPARINO: Well, too bad, pal.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: I mean, you know, that's what - you want to be a public company, you are going to have some regulations you have to follow. I will say this, though. MELISSA FRANCIS, Fox BUSINESS ANCHOR: The coming housing boom pegged to get this, America's young adults, never mind the fact that one in three still live with their parents and it is the biggest week for IPOs since 2006. A new study out of Harvard University finding that 35 percent of U.S. households can't afford their current living situation. With me now, "The Wall Street Journal's" Veronica Dagher, editor of "Power Trend Profits, Chris Versace and Dominick Tavella of Diversified Financial. Thanks to all of you for joining us. So, what that means is that their rent or their mortgage consumes 30 percent of their monthly income. I mean this is huge. This is 40 million Americans. For a lot of them it consumes 50 percent! Veronica, this is a disaster.

VERONICA DAGHER, Fox BUSINESS: It is a disaster especially because the more you spend on housing the less you have to spend on other things like consumer discretionary goods. And so that has larger effects to our economy. These people are spending so much on their rent they can't go be buying, you know, new cars or taking vacations. They just don't have the money.

FRANCIS: And a lot of the problems has to do with the fact that incomes aren't growing, right, Chris?

CHRIS VERSACE, POWERTREND PROFIST: Absolutely. I mean you look at all the jobs that we've seen created, but we look at the mix of those jobs, lower income jobs. So, there's not a lot of wage growth. We are seeing inflation across food and energy, and to your point, Veronica, disposable income is going to be tapped, so where are these people going to live?

FRANCIS: No, I mean among the other problems that creates when you look at the GDP print that we saw this week and just the big pullback, a lot of it had to do with consumer spending. You're not spending on discretionary goods if you have this much of your money going to your rent and mortgage, right?

DOMINICK TAVELLA, DIVERSIFIED FINANCIAL: Not only that. But it's the tax consequence what is happened in the first quarter. So, people paying much higher taxes than they were before. They are paying much higher in cost of living issues, even though the government says there is no cost of living. Cost of housing has gone through the roof. It really as depressed the average consumer what they can actually do out there.

FRANCIS: OK, more fallout from Barclays, over alleged dark pool fraud. Charlie Gasparino first reported New York's lawsuit against Barclay's right here on "MONEY." Now, they're getting the cold shoulder from several big name brokerage firms, including Deutsche Bank and the Royal Bank of Canada. Chris, this is an interesting one. Because it seems like dark pools, if you look at this, we may die their own death. If now people are afraid when they stay away from them. What do you think?

VERSACE: I think you're absolutely right on that. We are ultimately designed for, which was to allow large pools to be traded, you know, it's very anonymously, so people can move in and out. But where there is lot of smoke there is fire. The SEC is investigating. And all of a sudden what may have been once so safe may not be.

FRANCIS: Veronica.

VERONICA DAGHER, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": I think investors are going to be demanding more transparency in this case.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

DAGHER: They want to see what's going on. They're called dark pools for a reason.

FRANCIS: For a reason, right.

DAGHER: Yes.

FRANCIS: It is the opposite of transparency. That is the whole point.

DAGHER: That's right, yeah. And I think a lot of these firms that are stepping away from their connections to Barclays right now. You know, there is a PR component to this, too.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

And really, I mean, once again, it's just like such a big knock on Wall Street.

Having said that they need to have a credibility, a trust with the institution that they're doing it. That they're getting fair pricing. That trades are being done orderly and efficiently. And when that doesn't happen the trust gets cut.

FRANCIS: But it does have to do with the small investor because it's this idea that Wall Street is rigged. And there's more and more of these stories come out. So, if you're on the sidelines because you're paranoid you really lost out

FRANCIS: Yeah. All right, the federal government is set to auction off $17 million worth of bitcoin today. This is all courtesy of the shuttered online market silk road. The online sell is shrouded in secrecy, speaking of secrecy, and is attracting some financial power players. Veronica, I mean, this is an interesting one. If they just went ahead and put all this out on the open market, bitcoin, it would totally depress the price.

DAGHER: Yeah, it would sink the price. It's going to be interesting to see how the government handles this. You know, it's not like selling confiscated Chevys that they have got from drug bust.

(LAUGHTER)

DAGHER: So, how this plays out and how the investors, you know, I think there were investor lists, potential bidder lists released already. How that affects the bidding will be interesting to watch.

FRANCIS: Yeah, Chris, are you watching this one?

VERSACE: I'm watching it a little bit. I'm wondering why the government doesn't pull in like a currency trader or somebody in the know for dealing with this .

FRANCIS: I thought they were? They're not doing that?

VERSACE: You know, it sounds like they're doing it in-house. We know that they are not going to do it well. So, you know, how well can they leak this out? That's the big question.

FELIX: No. Actually I got a nice haircut when I was at camp last week. They decided to give me a bulkhead. Campers show up and turn the devices into a safe. Anything of value, locked up for four days and we never had anyone try to sneak out.

FRANCIS: Why do I want to go to a camp and pay for this? I want to detox, I can put it to the side. People need to go somewhere and have it physically taken from them in order to do it?

FELIX: We are focused on the unplugging, it is what you are looking to reconnect with. There is yoga, meditation, hiking, different arts and crafts programs, our jury, full on summer camp for adults. We trade space where people can put away their phones so they are not going to get work e- mail's for calls anywhere from 385 to 574 four days, we do all organic sustainable food. Basically like a cruise ship but in the redwoods for four days and pretty amazing what happens when you have 300 adults altogether, everyone is hanging out and singing together.

FRANCIS: I am about to go on a cruise and trying to think of which two vacations I would rather do. Levi, thank you so much. No phones for this one. Instead of e-mailing his resume look at what this guy did. He printed his resume on a pack of beer.

Graphic designer, Brennan Gleeson started Resumemail at the University of Frazier Valley in addition to his crafty labeling, he broods the beer himself. Apparently the companies he sent it to drank up the idea. He says he got a few offers right away. What do you think of this? Pretty clever.

DAGHER: Nice to see an entrepreneur. These ideas don't often work. People sending balloons and flowers and kind of tacky, but for a graphic designer he is showing talent. It is really creative.

FRANCIS: I heard someone wrapping up resume around a pineapple. Put on coffee because it perks everyone up. There you go. If there is one thing Americans are great at in a World Cup is the ability to lose a game and still get ahead. Asking anything about the point system and how it works, listen to who is getting that hilariously and publicly wrong. At the end of the day it is all about money and a very complex score keeping.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Well, we didn't win it, but we're in it. Team USA advances in the World Cup game despite its loss to Germany yesterday all thanks to the point system. If you didn't get the math of sports here, you are not alone. Dennys made the same mistake, going to eat my wait in ice cream now because of sadness.

Jonathan Hoenig and Scott Martin are back with me now. I mean, they're trying to tweet and stay on top of it, but apparently they didn't realize we were still in. What do you think, Jonathan?

JONATHAN HOENIG, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, soccer is still just an unknown entity for so many of us here in the states, Melissa, so I take the same approach that I do with stocks, you have to kind of go where the action is.

FRANCIS: Yes.

HOENIG: Call me when we're in the finals.

SCOTT MARTIN: Come on --

FRANCIS: Go ahead, Scott.

MARTIN: Jonathan, don't make my come over there again. This is big for the country though. Everybody is getting fired up about this. The sad thing about Dennys, Melissa, they didn't give out free food because the USA lost.

FRANCIS: I didn't really watch yesterday. I tried to, but apparently all of Wall Street did. Volume of shares traded during the game yesterday, 25 percent lower than the same time as last year. Scott, you were watching, yes? Were you trading or watching?

MARTIN: I was definitely watching. And the funny thing is, you know, if you're at a restaurant watch how many people pile in there, and the second the game is over, it's like a stampede out the door. But it's good business for these restaurants. If you open up your business for some of these fans, you get people spending money, and I think it's good.

FRANCIS: Absolutely, Jonathan, I guess I wasn't alone not watching because even astronauts in space tuned in, American and German astronauts at the International Space Station celebrated their teams advancing with a little victory dancing. Do we have that video? What do you think? Jonathan, did you see this?

HOENIG: I didn't see that, but I'm not surprised. I mean, sporting events like this, Melissa, give us the opportunity to come together for a shared experience and celebrate the good, the good for being the good, the heroic nature of these really incredible athletes who are able to run for I don't know how long, how hard, their endurance is remarkable. So the fact that we can all get together and cheer, a positive thing.

FRANCIS: Absolutely. Gentlemen, thanks to both of you. Happy Friday to everyone out there. I don't know about you, but these guys here in the studio are ready to get the weekend started, right, guys? Yes. All right, "COUNTDOWN" starts right now.

END
