Growing Questions Surrounding Bruce Ohr's Involvement In Russia Probe; Giuliani Expresses 'Perjury Trap' Concerns; Omarosa Attacks Trump White House; Plane Thief Raises Airport Security Concerns; President Trump Signed Today In Fort Drum, Utica, the $716 Billion Defense Bill That Gives The Largest Pay Raise To The Military In Nine years; Republican Critic Who Wrote The Book "Everything Trump Touches Dies" Cannot Give A Specific Answer To What Actually Died Under The Trump Administration; Family Of Tim Piazza Who Died In Hazing Almost Two Years Now Continues His Legacy And Puts Up A Foundation That Would Help Fund For Prosthetic Devices For Children In Need And Scholarships For Students

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: The new bride climbs out of the car. She makes it through the escape to the sunroof. They actually get to the wedding and pull it off. There you go.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for this SPECIAL REPORT. Fair, balanced and unafraid. "THE STORY, hosted by my friend, Martha McCallum, starts right now. That's determination, Martha.

MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS HOST: Yes, it's -- you never really wear that dress again anyway, you know?

BAIER: Yes.

MACCALLUM: Thank you, Bret. Good to see you. So, breaking tonight, Congressman Trey Gowdy joins us with his reaction tonight to the firing of the veteran FBI agent who ran both the Clinton and Trump campaign investigations and who wrote this, just to remind you, among other similar things during the 2016 election. "Just went to a southern Virginia Walmart. I could smell the Trump support.

The question now was this one firing enough to change the culture? And what about the other three unnamed FBI agents so far who according to the Inspector General report should be investigated for their politically charged text messages.

Good evening everybody. I'm Martha MacCallum. My next guest is no stranger to this story and Peter Strzok.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

REP. TREY GOWDY (R-SC), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE: Stays into your Russian collusion with the Trump campaign investigation. And you got another text from your colleague, Lisa Page. "Trump's not ever going to become president, right?" Right? And you replied, "No, no he's not. We'll stop it. I want to know what it meant agent Strzok.

PETER STRZOK, FORMER DEPUTY ASSISTANT DIRECTOR, FBI: It would be his candidacy.

GOWDY: March of 2016, you wrote, "God, Hillary should win a hundred million to zero. And March of 2016, weren't you investigating her for potential mishandling of classified information?

STRZOK: We were.

GOWDY: Had you interviewed her yet?

STRZOK: No, but I don't appreciate what was originally said being changed.

GOWDY: I don't give a damn what you appreciate agent Strzok. I don't appreciate having an FBI agent with an unprecedented level of animus working on two major investigations during 2016.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MACCALLUM: Just a sampling of some of the water that's gone under the bridge. Here now, exclusively with his reaction to all of this tonight is Congressman Trey Gowdy of South Carolina.

Congressman, welcome. Good to have you here on THE STORY tonight.

GOWDY: Yes, ma'am. Thank you.

MACCALLUM: Were you surprised by this outcome that he was fired at this point and why do you think it happened now?

GOWDY: I think the process had just reached the point where it was a Deputy Director at Bowditch's desk. I mean, keep in mind, Peter Strzok receives a much fairer process than what he was given to Donald Trump.

This was a referral by the inspector general who if memory serves was an Obama appointee. Michael Horowitz referred it. It was investigated by OPR. Strzok has a chance to defend himself from participate in the process and submit extra material. And then, a recommendation is made with respect to punishment.

And Deputy Director Bowditch is not a political appointee. He is a 23-year long bureau agent who served with great distinction including running the Los Angeles field office. That's who made the decision to terminate Peter Strzok. It was not a political appointee, it was a career G-Man.

MACCALLUM: Well, his attorney doesn't agree with you. Here he is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AITAN GOELMAN, ATTORNEY FOR PETER STRZOK: I don't think that you can rationally reach any conclusion other than it was political. It's difficult to believe given the steady drumbeat of texts demonizing Pete from the President and all the calls on Capitol Hill by Republicans for Pete to be fired that, that didn't play a role in the Bureau's ultimate decision.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: So, he essentially says that you demonized Peter Strzok and that you played a role in his firing.

GOWDY: No, Peter Strzok didn't need any help at all demonizing himself. He had that fully covered. This is exactly what they said about Andy McCabe, remember?

And some of my Democrat colleagues were going to hire Andy McCabe, so he could finish out his time at the bureau. I don't know if you remember that. I can't forget it.

Peter Strzok -- of course, his lawyer says that it was a railroad job. There's the only other option is to say, "You know what, my client prejudged two major investigations.

He made up his mind that Hillary Clinton was innocent before he interviewed her. He made up his mind that Donald Trump should be impeached before he bothered to interview him. And no other way he did a lot of this on the government phone, and he violated other FBI policy.

That's his other option. Either say that or say it was political and predictably, if you pay someone enough, Martha, they'll say damn near anything. Particularly, lawyers and he got a lawyer who's willing to say it's political.

MACCALLUM: All right. So, the Inspector General as I mentioned at the beginning of the program also said that there were a few other FBI agents who had sent similarly bias and politically motivated apparently text messages.

What's going on with them? Or are we going to hear more about this investigation and do you think that this Peter Strzok firing is enough in terms of the culture?

GOWDY: Well, Chairman Goodlatte and I have written asking for the names of those Bureau and DOJ employees, apparently, according to DOJ and Bureau policy, they don't rise to the level of their names being shared with Congress. But there I'm sure under investigation.

Just like those were a referral from Horowitz on Strzok. There was a referral on these, some of what they said is just unbelievable. Particularly, about their fellow citizens, particularly people who live in Ohio. You mentioned the smelling people in Virginia, they also had something really derogatory to say about folks in Ohio.

So, I am sure they will be afforded all of the process that they're due. But again, Martha, it is more than Strzok was willing to afford the President of the United States. They have a chance to defend themselves and there will be a recommendation made. And then, ultimately, Deputy Director Bowditch will decide whether or not to follow it.

You asked if it's enough. There have been 10 folks that were involved in the Hillary Clinton investigation and Donald Trump investigation that are no longer with the bureau. Lots of them were really high up.

Instead of focusing on the firings, I have focused on the hirings. Chris Wray and David Bowditch, I am convinced, are going to be able to repair the institutional reputation of the Bureau.

99.9 percent of the agents don't need their reputation to improve because it's already really good, but they're going to take the FBI back to what we remember it being. So it's the two hiring's that I'm most excited about.

MACCALLUM: Yes, yes. And you make a good point. I mean, the DOJ and the FBI have done housecleaning clearly. So, they clearly think that there was a problem with 10 individuals who were involved in this investigation, and they are no longer there.

I want to ask you about these Bruce Ohr text messages because I'm curious what you think about him. Because he's kind of being at the back of this story for a while. But now that we're reading, and I know you read quite a while ago the message that he sent to Christopher Steele who, of course, was the person behind the dossier. Here's one from July 1.

"I am seeing a redacted person in London next week to discuss ongoing business, but there is something separate I wanted to discuss with you informally and separately. It concerns our favorite business tycoon." Your thoughts on that one.

GOWDY: Bruce Ohr, who work for the Department of Justice. He had absolutely nothing to do with the Russia investigation other than he inserted himself by having contact with Chris Steele. Martha, he even had contact with Chris Steele after the FBI terminated its relationship with Chris Steele.

So, this is one branch of the Department of Justice that says you're not even fit to be an informant and here's a DOJ. I think he may have been third in command. We're going to interview him on August 28th.

I am going to come back to Washington. I'm going to leave my beloved South Carolina, and I'm going to go back. And I'm sure others will too. Jimmy and Mark and Ratcliffe. We're going to be back, and we're going to interview Bruce Ohr, not in a public circus setting, but any deposition with no time limits.

And we're going to get to the bottom of what he did, why he did it, who he did it in concert with, whether he had the permission of the supervisors at the Department of Justice?

It is. I used to work doing what Bruce Ohr does now. It is unbelievable that a prosecutor would insert himself into an ongoing investigation for which he had nothing to do.

MACCALLUM: Yes, well one thing you had to do was that his wife worked for Fusion GPS who was working on --

GOWDY: There is that.

MACCALLUM: Who was working on the dossier and we will -- is that going to be open or closed testimony with Bruce Ohr?

GOWDY: Yes, we don't behave that well when the cameras are in there, Martha. So, we're going to do it in a closed confidential private setting where everybody behaves and it's much more constructive.

MACCALLUM: All right. I want to ask you about Rudy Giuliani, and what he said this weekend with regard to perjury traps, and whether or not the president should sit down with Robert Mueller. Let's play that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUDY GIULIANI, ATTORNEY TO PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: There was no conversation about Michael Flynn. I think it was February when it supposedly took place. Memo came out in May, and in between Comey testified under oath that in no way had he been obstructed at any time.

And then, all of a sudden in May, he says he felt obstructed. He felt pressured by that comment, you should go easy on Flynn. So, we maintained the president didn't say that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: It was indicated prior to that statement that the president talked about it but that he meant nothing by it that it didn't constitute obstruction. So, what do you make of all of this, congressman?

GOWDY: Well, there are only two people that know whether or not it came up. One is President Trump and the other is Jim Comey. I think, the better line of analysis, and again, I'm not the president's lawyer, and he can do better than me. But, there are four elements to perjury. It has to be under oath, it has to be material, it has to be intentional.

The falsehood has to be intentional. I think, the president, if he doesn't remember that coming up, that's a perfectly acceptable answer. I don't remember Ohr, that's not what I recall, or I don't think I phrased it that way.

Martha, I will tell you this. If it is obstruction of justice to ask someone to show leniency, then we're going to have to build a lot more prisons in this country, and they're going to be preachers in most of them.

For 20 years I had preachers called me and asked me to please give this person a second chance, please show some leniency. That is not obstruction of justice. That is what happens all across this country every day. And Jim Comey must not have felt obstructed because he kept working for the guy.

MACCALLUM: Yes. And he claimed an open testimony that no one had interfered with his investigation. I have to go but I want to ask you one more quick question. In the Manafort trial, the judge appears to have been quite hard on Mueller's team.

You have been very supportive, and a proponent of the integrity of Mueller's team. Did what you hear in there affect your opinion about that at all?

GOWDY: It affects my opinion on the judge. The fact that you and I are talking about a judge. They're supposed to be neutral detached arbiters, referees, umpires. The fact that he inserts himself -- whether I supported the prosecution or the defense is immaterial, judges are not active participants in the trial.

And I've been in front of some tough ones. I've never been in front of one who enjoyed hearing his name and enjoyed being the star of the show as much as this one. And I frankly feel sorry for the -- for the lawyers on both sides that they're having to put up with a judge up who was confusing himself with the deity.

MACCALLUM: Congressman Trey Gowdy, always good to see you, sir. Thank you very much for coming in tonight.

GOWDY: Yes, ma'am. You too.

MACCALLUM: You bet. So, coming up next. Omarosa, claims now that she has Jared and Ivanka on tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OMAROSA MANIGAULT NEWMAN, FORMER WHITE HOUSE DIRECTOR OF COMMUNICATIONS, OFFICE OF PUBLIC LIAISON: There's a lot of very corrupt things that are happening in the White House and I am going to blow the whistle on a lot of that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Oh boy, what a drama this is. Governor Mike Huckabee knows all the players and he is here, next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NEWMAN: I'm in the room and I can only speak for myself because civil rights is a priority for this President. What's happening in the inner cities is a priority for this President. The coalition's that I work with, they're priorities for this President. This is our second day here and I think that this President has accomplished more in two days than most presidents have in a very long time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: So that interview was here during the first hundred days but after Omarosa was fired by John Kelly, she started singing a very different tune. She had been secretly taping private conversations in the White House and tonight there is some indication that those might include more tapes that perhaps have Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump we won't we -- won't know unless those actually are released but obviously a lot of this is to trump up her book so to speak. Trace Gallagher is live in our West Coast Newsroom with the backstory tonight. Hi Trace!

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Hi Martha! The first part of Omarosa Manigault Newman's book tour has certainly been riddled with credibility problems. She's been done in by her own words. For example, she now says she heard Donald Trump on tape using a racial slur but in her book, she claims somebody else told her about the slur. Then there was the "why she or wasn't she fired?" The recording she released today appears to show the President being surprised that Omarosa was leaving the White House. Listen to this.

(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Omarosa, what's going on. I just saw in the news that you're thinking about leaving. What happened?

NEWMAN: General Kelly -- General Kelly came to me and said that you guys wanted me to leave.

TRUMP: No, nobody even told me about it.

(END AUDIO CLIP)

GALLAGHER: Omarosa now claims and the White House appears to support that it was President Trump who "delegated her firing." Listen to the tape Manigault Newman released of White House Chief of Staff John Kelly letting her go followed by what she told Good Morning America after she left the White House in December of last year. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN KELLY, WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: I think it's important to understand and if we make this a friendly departure, we can all be you know, you can -- you can look at look at your time here in the White House as a year of service to the nation and then you can go on without any type of difficulty in the future relative to your reputation.

NEWMAN: I resigned and I didn't do that in the residence as being reported. John Kelly and I sat down in the Situation Room which is a very secure, very quiet room in the White House and we had a very candid conversation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GALLAGHER: Now, experts are torn on whether recording conversations in the Situation Room is illegal but they agree it is a clear violation of national security regulations. But on the Today Show, Manigault Newman says she's not worried about the fallout. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NEWMAN: I have protections. The moment that I've decided to blow the whistle on a lot of the corruption going on in the White House, there are protections that (INAUDIBLE) to me so let's be clear. The things that general Kelly is joining in this White House should concern all Americans.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GALLAGHER: President Trump responded "while I know it's not presidential to take on a low-life like Omarosa and while I would rather not be doing so, this is a modern-day form of communication and I know the fake news media will be working overtime to make even whacky Omarosa look legitimate as possible. Sorry." And Martha, you mentioned at the top Omarosa claims to have tapes of Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner, Politico is now reporting those tapes say that they wished her the best and had no idea that she had been fired at the time.

MACCALLUM: Very interesting. Trace, thank you. Governor Mike Huckabee former Presidential Candidate and Fox News Contributor joins me now. Governor, obviously you know a lot of the people that are involved in all of this. Does any of this really surprise you and when you listen to the tape with John Kelly, is there anything surprising about that conversation?

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: You know, there is, Martha. When I listened to John Kelly kind of letting her down easy I'm thinking that is the most gentle general I've ever seen when he's firing somebody.

MACCALLUM: She says he was threatening her.

HUCKABEE: No he wasn't threatening her. He was just making it very clear that she had some integrity issues, that she wasn't going to be able to say, that it was non-negotiable. He was calm, he was rational, but he was very firm and clear that she was going to have to go. I just can't believe that she has betrayed the President like this. You know, this is a person who a year ago was saying what a wonderful guy he was and now you know, she's thinking he's just awful and everybody in the White House is awful. So either she was lying then or she's lying now, the one thing we know is that she's a liar and she may be lying both times. The point is she has zero credibility.

And here's what I find interesting, Martha. All these various news outlets that are just begging her to come on and spill stuff about the president, I mean they're going to drop her faster than a plastic straw in California as soon as they use her all up. And she still doesn't realize that she's not going to be some celebrity because of what she's done because nobody will ever be able to trust her.

MACCALLUM: Yes, I mean, anybody who watched five minutes of The Apprentice could have figured out that this was going to happen, that this was going to end badly so you know, the one I think fair criticism here, Governor Huckabee, is why they would ever have hired this person who is you know, a reality T.V. show actress in the first place?

HUCKABEE: That's a fair criticism of the President. Why did he -- why did he ever hire her? Now, maybe it was sympathy, maybe it was that she had been a loyal campaigner and he thought you know, well hey, I'll give her a job but it's pretty apparent she was way over her head, didn't really have a function or a role, and ultimately was a troublemaker but not necessarily a problem solver. And that kind of person shouldn't be on the federal payroll.

So yes, I agree with you. I think it's fair to say that she should have been vetted more. They should have had a clear direction for what she was going to do. But when they realized she was not going to get better they let her go and she was fine until she was able to start hawking her book and suddenly you know, the guy who had been the greatest thing since the invention of the wheel now became worse than the wicked witch of the west at a water park. I just think it's disingenuous on her part but it's ludicrous on the part of the media who held her in such contempt before to now think she's some kind of Joan of Arc and so wonderful and how great it is that she has this courage to speak. She's just trying to make a buck and she sold her soul to do it and it's sad.

MACCALLUM: Governor Mike Huckabee, the saga continues on this one I think for a while. We'll see where it goes. Thank you, sir. Good to see you tonight.

HUCKABEE: Thank you, Martha.

MACCALLUM: You bet. Always good to have you here. All right, so how does a plane get stolen and flown from a major U.S. Airport in the post 9/11 era. Our own Lea Gabrielle, a former Navy pilot is here with the shocking truth about that.

(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

RICHARD RUSSELL, SEATTLE PLANE THIEF: I've got a lot of people that care about me and it's going to disappoint them to hear that I did this. I'm just a broken guy, got a few screws loose I guess. Never really knew it until now.

(END AUDIO CLIP)

(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: He came flying out of the cargo area.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Call and scramble now.

RUSSELL: -- going to try to do a barrel roll. And if that goes good, then I'm going to go nose down and call it a night.

(END AUDIO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: Unbelievable. Those are the final words from the airport employee who hijacked an empty plane and flew it for an hour before crashing on Friday night. The incident, of course, raises security concerns all across the country. Investigators say that 29-year-old Richard Russell who you can see tragically flying that plane. He did loop- the-loops, a barrel roll. He was a ground service worker at Seattle-Tacoma Airport known as SeaTac and he simply pushed the 76 cedar turboprop back from a maintenance area and then took off without authorization.

The big question tonight is how could he do that? Lea Gabrielle, Fox News Correspondent, and former Navy pilot, Lea, thank you for coming in tonight. It's good to have you here. The family spoke out today and I just want to play this. This is the family and friends of Richard Russell. Watch.

MIKE MATTHEWS, FAMILY FRIEND OF RICHARD RUSSELL: He was a faithful husband, a loving son, and a good friend. A childhood friend remarked that Bebo was loved by everyone because he was kind and gentle to each person who he met. This is a complete shock to us. We are devastated by these events and Jesus is truly the only one holding this family together right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: You know he said himself there are people who care about me who are going to be so disappointed in what I'm doing. And you know obviously this is a tragedy for this family but it also raises so many questions about having a terrorist who's trained and gets himself a job working at an airport could do the same thing with disastrous results for other people.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: That is absolutely true, Martha. One of the questions I keep getting about this story is how could somebody steal an airplane? It is actually very easy to steal an airplane because they're not set up to have large amounts of security. This Airport has security but this person had been screened. In fact, this airport had added additional screening the past year and a half where you had to have biometrics and you had to be badged if you were allowed to operate in that area. So he was within the circle of trust. That's where that security falls for that air -- that airfield.

But when you think about flying an airplane, they're designed to fly. They're not that hard to fly. There are many airports around the country that don't have that level of security where somebody can literally walk out on to the airfield get in an airplane if they can get inside the cockpit, they can fly it. So it's not that surprising. Now, I will say you know, one word of caution when people are nervous about this is that this is a person who didn't have any red flags. This is a person who didn't have something in his background that would have indicated that he was trouble or that he might do something wrong or to harm other people and certainly it doesn't seem as though he intended to hurt anyone.

MACCALLUM: Yes, but the biggest concern here is that so -- and this has been a concern in since after 9/11 that's somebody, anybody who wanted to become a terrorist, get his hands on a plane could work in an airport. You could be there for five years. You could have a perfectly clean record. You could be a sleeper agent. And then you have this access. Why isn't there a key? Why aren't the planes locked? Why shouldn't you have some sort of finger- maker or anything to allow you to get on the plane?

GABRIELLE: It's a really good question. And the reason is because of the logistics. You know, when you go to, you know, to get on a flight to so somewhere you want efficiency and you want your ticket prices to be lower. Well, all those things decrease deficiency.

If you have to lock the aircraft then somebody has to have a key to get in the maintainers who are in charge of moving it around. If an airplane lands and goes to one gate and then it needs to be move to another, they have maintainers on the ground who are trusted their credentials to be able to do that.

MACCALLUM: Wow.

GABRIELLE: So it changes things. Airplanes are easy to fly but not easy to land though and then not easy to maneuver. There's a lot of simulators that you can find online that teach you how to flip the right switches and get it airborne.

MACCALLUM: They are more and more automatic and more and more able to able to plan their own than ever.

GABRIELLE: The rules are written in blood and I think that we will see more rules because of this incident.

MACCALLUM: Lea Gabrielle, thank you very much. Good to have you here tonight.

So, coming up next, a word of warning. Before you Google, how the tech company has violated its own promises to protect your privacy. Wait until you hear what your simple search is getting you. Steve Hilton with the story, next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have the best spirit, the best soldiers ever to set foot on any battlefield anywhere at any time. We are the most powerful. We are the best funded. We are the biggest. We are the strongest. We are the smartest. And we are still not holding a damn thing because America is on the move once again and we are not backing down.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: That holding reference was from a Patton, quote, "that the president was talking about today about moving forward and not holding your position."

That was President Trump at Fort Drum earlier today signaling -- signing, rather, a $716 billion defense policy bill giving the largest pay raise to the military in nine years.

The president's support among the military is just one of many topics that I discussed with outspoken Republican Rick Wilson earlier today. He is the author of the new book "Everything Trump Touches Dies." Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MACCALLUM: When you watch that and you watch him speaks at the military, he got a very positive response there today. What goes through your mind?

RICK WILSON, Republican STRATEGIST: Look, Donald Trump has speechwriters like every other president's speechwriters. What I worry about is not what's prepared for him to say in an event like this. What I worry about is the impulsive nature of this president.

Because look, I'm not -- I'm not some liberal rhino squash who wants the president to, you know, become, you know, pro-abortion or anything with that. I'm a conservative and I believe that the power of the presidency is a sacred power. And I believe that the government needs to have a perspective from someone who is a mindful leader and follows in the traditions of our greatest presidents, and I find that Donald Trump doesn't meet those standards.

MACCALLUM: So let me say this. When I, you know, reading your book--

WILSON: Sure.

MACCALLUM: -- that's the thing that really I think speaks the loudest. What I get from it in many ways, is you don't like him, you don't like his style, you are offended by him.

And a lot of people that I talked to across the country, I always ask people what they think about the president as I'm sure you do.

WILSON: Sure.

MACCALLUM: As somebody who cares about politics and cares about the country. And what I hear from many people is, I don't like him, but I like his policy. I like what he's doing. And I get it. I hear that over and over. People pull me aside and say, here's what I think. I'm not crazy about him, but I like what he is doing. So--

WILSON: I think you're right, Martha. A lot of people likes some of the things that are happening because of policy matters. But a lot of those policy things are unfortunately very temporary. A lot of the things--

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: All right. Just tell me about the things that you talk that die.

WILSON: Sure.

MACCALLUM: What has died in--

(CROSSTALK)

WILSON: Well, look, everyone who works for Donald Trump at some point is going to hit the wall and their life is going to turn into one moment they are on the top of the mountain. One moment Omarosa is the best friend in the world and she's wonderful and she's in the inner circle. And the next minute she is wacky--

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: But do you think Omarosa matters to most Americans. I mean, I talk to Americans running businesses in this country, right? You look at the numbers. You look at corporate support for the president, CEO support, small business support up 14 percent, up 19 percent. Consumer confidence is very high under this president.

So they look at what's going on and they are separating out the man from the policies, and they are saying, you know what, I have a lot less regulation on my business, I'm opening up a new plant. I'm expanding the people that I'm employing here. And I feel like that matters to people that I speak to in the country way more than these other stuff.

WILSON: Well, look, it may matter to some people about that. But I will say this. We are still sitting on a gigantic ocean of quantitative easing cheap money from the Fed that started during Obama and continued on the--

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: All right, that's the given when he walks in the door.

WILSON: It is. I am not blaming or praising him.

MACCALLUM: Right.

WILSON: That has had a large economic impact. The fact that we passed the massive tax bill have a simulative effect, no question about it. But it also is going to come with a price.

MACCALLUM: So then how do you explain consumer confidence numbers. Up 14 percent under Trump. That's not hedge fund guys. That's guys who run businesses.

(CROSSTALK)

WILSON: Look--

MACCALLUM: The majority of the economy in this country as you well know is small business.

WILSON: Well, Martha--

MACCALLUM: So I'm just asking this what died? What died?

WILSON: Every person that works for Donald Trump.

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: You said that. What else died?

WILSON: In fact, the Republican Party used to stand for the rule of law.

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: So what rule of law is--

WILSON: This is a president who is at war with the FBI, at war with the Justice Department who believes he operates in an extra judicial fashion in a lot of different ways.

And you see him frequently acting as if he is not a person who works for the people but he acts more in that sort of status and more authoritarian flavor and he's got a deal of affection for that kind of style and that kind of leadership overseas.

And I will say this. Donald Trump he is a character that people bought into. And they love that character. They love the big broad acting of, you know, acting on his emotions and all of that other stuff. And I will say this. The people that have worked for him have come to grief almost all of them.

All these people that were inside and once they move out, they become un- person.

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: All right. But so, Rick, wait, wait, wait. Indulge me here for a second.

WILSON: Sure.

MACCALLUM: Because you work in Washington, right?

(CROSSTALK)

WILSON: I work in Florida, I say in Washington.

MACCALLUM: You know a lot of these -- OK. You work in Florida. OK, you work in politics.

WILSON: Yes.

MACCALLUM: You work in politics for a long time. Most people in America don't work in politics.

WILSON: Sure.

MACCALLUM: So you have sympathy, perhaps for people in the meat grinder of this process and who don't like or who have left, right. I'm not sure again that that is something that has died for most Americans across this country.

(CROSSTALK)

WILSON: Well, look, the other thing that died that is the Republican agenda beyond the executive order.

MACCALLUM: So then why do 87 percent of Republicans support the president?

WILSON: We have a great tribal system now in this country whether the tribal media side on the right, the tribal media are on the left. And there are few people left in the center. And a lot of it becomes self-reinforcing and self-referential. And then there are basically TV networks on the right and TV networks on the left, media on the right, media on the left.

MACCALLUM: I know, but I don't give a whole lot of credit to TV networks even though I work for one. A few million people watch television every day.

WILSON: Sure.

MACCALLUM: A 120 million people voted in the last presidential election. Most of them are not swayed one way or the other. As much as you and I like to think that we have an impact on what people think or what they read or what they listen to--

(CROSSTALK)

WILSON: I will tell you--

MACCALLUM: -- most of us don't have a big impact on their daily lives.

WILSON: I will tell you this. One thing that had a big impact and we saw this and a lot of folks, (Inaudible) voters voted in 2016 where you'd sit there behind the glass and listen to these interviews and they'd say well, Donald Trump is a decisive leader and he's a good manager and he's great at international developing.

They were listening to the character they knew from television. They watched him on the apprentice for 14 years. And the character in the White House is different person. All this impulsive tweeting, all this, you know, back and forth the things that he believes he's accomplished with like--

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: But I'm just saying to you that when I -- you know, the people who -- a lot of people go, I don't really care about the tweets. So what do you say to them? I mean, I know it bothers you personally and I get that.

WILSON: No.

MACCALLUM: But what I'm looking at when I look across the spectrum, you know, you look at more money going to NATO, you look at shaking the chess board up with North Korea and Iran, putting them in a different position. And who knows? I mean, the outcome may be disastrous.

(CROSSTALK)

WILSON: I think--

MACCALLUM: Or it may be very good. We don't know the answer to that question yet. So I'm still curious when you say that everything he touched dies, so far what I've got is you know, staffers who are unhappy and left and norms?

WILSON: Well, and also the long held Republican belief, we were going to be the party that its gets deficit under control, we were going to be the party that--

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: Well, that's been a problem for plenty of Republican presidents. And you're absolutely right.

WILSON: -- certainly announced--

MACCALLUM: President Trump has done nothing to make that better.

WILSON: -- certainly announced. And we were also the party that was going to shrink the size of government. And Donald Trump while there's been some regulatory tweaking is proposing wild expansions of the size and scope of power of the federal government and a whole bund of areas.

MACCALLUM: But you haven't name anything that he's done that died essentially when it comes to the kind of thing that you're talking about.

WILSON: Well.

MACCALLUM: And as I said before I think that--

(CROSSTALK)

WILSON: We're still -- we're still stuck with Obamacare.

MACCALLUM: -- while people may care about the people who work in Washington and work in the White House and think that some of them are nice people and they might be--

WILSON: Sure.

MACCALLUM: -- I'm sorry they left their job. I'm not sure something that they care about when sit down to dinner. Rick, before I let you go, do you think he would win again if the election were held today?

WILSON: Well, the Democrats have an infinite capacity to screw up campaigns. So he's got three in five chance right now if the Democrats put up, you know, one of the -- one of the usual suspects.

MACCALLUM: Yes. Interesting. Rick Wilson, thank you very much. Good talking to you.

WILSON: Thank you, Martha.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MACCALLUM: So here now, Steve Hilton, host of The Next Revolution and a Fox News contributor. So, Steve, you listen to that conversation I think it's very interesting, you know, politically to talk to people who support President Trump, people who are never Trumpers to try to analyze, you know, where things are going to be for that side of the equation when the next election rolls around, and try to sort of poke some holes in some of these theories that don't really match up with what we are seeing in terms of a lot of the numbers and a lot of people's reactions out there. What did you think, what did you take away from him?

STEVE HILTON, HOST, FOX NEWS: Well, my main take away, Martha, was what an amazing interview. I was watching that and every moment when he said something, I wanted to jump in. I was literally sitting here and wanted to jump in and you said the exact same thing that I would have said.

And I just thought you really exposed how thin his argument is. When the first line of your argument is Omarosa and you can't really get beyond staffing issues, it really shows that there is nothing much to it.

Because frankly, this -- by the way, he is a guy that I know and I think that he is a good guy, you know, and he's true. He is right when he said he is a conservative and so on.

But in the end, all of those people in that never Trump camp, what they really object to and you really expose that is the style and not the substance. And what really matters to people's lives is the substance where he is making really big progress not just in the economic area that you highlighted that because the most important.

I mean, he said, for example, the changes that maybe good they're not permanent. They're kind of fleeting. How can you say that about Gorsuch and hopefully now Kavanaugh? Those are really lasting changes.

And the other thing I'd point to which is a really lasting change and they are really big deal but you can't even that some of the never Trumpers do kind of give the credit to the Republican Party or Congress and not really give any credit to Trump which is often what they do with the tax bill.

Look at China, what President Trump has done and this is really coming directly from him and not anyone else, is finally recognize that our number one strategic enemy in this century is China. And he completely recalibrated our relationship with China.

That is a really historic shift in policy. And I think that these are all examples of where the underlying substance of this administration is really solid and delivering results.

MACCALLUM: Yes. We will see. And I always think back to the people I met on the campaign trails who said they wanted someone who would change things up on the Republican side.

HILTON: Right.

MACCALLUM: And clearly he is a disrupter. There is no doubt about that. You are a disrupter when it comes to technology. You are a person who is not an adapter. And when I read this piece today about Google if you turn off the location devices, it means basically nothing.

HILTON: Yes.

MACCALLUM: They are still tracking you and looking at what you being looking at all the time, right?

HILTON: Exactly. And it's similar throughout the tech sector. You get it also with Facebook, for example, where they are following what you do online even if you are not actually on Facebook.

MACCALLUM: Crazy. So crazy.

HILTON: And so the thing that we have to understand about these big tech companies which I know very well, is that really if you think about their business, what they actually are, a data gathering company. That is their business. That is how they make money.

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: Making money off of everything that anyone of us look for?

HILTON: Yes. Now sometimes that can -- what they say is when we gather all this information and then we can use that to give you useful services. For example, if you want to find, I don't know, shops near you that are selling something that are still open. That's useful for you.

But in the process the idea of privacy has basically disappeared. There isn't really no way to opt out of it. I as you hinted out opted out in a very drastic way. I don't have a Smartphone at all, I haven't had one for six years because I don't think that's a solution for most people.

MACCALLUM: I really admire that about you. I got to tell you, because I would love to leave my Smartphone behind. But I get like a little bit of like, you know, I get a panic attack if I'm far from it for too long.

HILTON: Of course.

MACCALLUM: Like most Americans do I think. Thank you so much. Good to see you tonight, Steve. Great to have on the show as always.

HILTON: Thanks, Martha. See you soon. Bye.

MACCALLUM: OK. You bet. I look forward to it.

So days after a second guilty plea in the tragic hazing death of Tim Piazza, his family is working to carry on his legacy and try to turn things around on campuses as students head back to school this fall.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIM PIAZZA, TIM PIAZZA'S FATHER: He didn't let us down. The people that killed him let us down. I think he would be looking down at us and he would be proud of the fact that we are carrying this torch and hopefully saving other people in the future.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACCALLUM: So less than a week after a 2nd so-called brother pleaded guilty to charges relating to Tim Piazza's hazing death, Tim's parents push to carry on his legacy tonight.

So today is the second annual Timothy Piazza Memorial Foundation golf tournament. The money raised is used in part to help fund prosthetic devices for children in need and scholarships for students. And we have shared some of those stories with you over the course of the last year.

Tim's father, Jim Piazza joins me live from the event where the auction is underway. And we hope they are raising a lot of money tonight in Tim's name.

But Jim, I do want to ask you about the recent sentencing that happened for two of the individuals who were involved in what happened to Tim. And one of them was Ryan Burke, and you made a very emotional statement of the personal loss that you suffered.

Do you feel that what he got as the rush (Ph) chairman 27 months of probation and 100 hours of community service is the right punishment?

PIAZZA: Well, you know, we are not judges. We don't really know what the right amount of punishment should be. We are looking for justice for Tim. He was the first one to step up. So we are hopeful that it sets a precedent and you know, from there moving forward, we have appropriate justice with the rest of the individuals that really had a more meaningful role in the whole incident.

MACCALLUM: Yes. Do you think that that will prompt others to step forward? Do you think it will?

PIAZZA: We are hoping so. We're hoping that others, you know, see that, you know, that he and the other individuals stepped up and they will follow suit. Obviously, the evidence is there. There is a video. There is no denying, you know, what happened that night. The video speaks for itself.

MACCALLUM: yes, indeed, it does. And you know, you and your wife Evelyn won an award for the work that you have done against hazing. And as I think so many students are heading back to college campuses, some of them for the first time, some of them will be rushing this fall.

What is -- what's your message to those families? What should they say to their children as they head off and would you discourage them from participating at all?

PIAZZA: No, we're not trying to discourage participation in Greek life. I mean, our message is, you know, make sure that your children are well informed, they're smart. And when they decide to rush, if they are asked to do something that they are uncomfortable with, just don't do it. And buddy up with other people so that you can walk away.

Hopefully by this point the Greek organizations are smarter and they are not getting involved in these chaotic rituals that we saw in our situation.

MACCALLUM: It's so awful what happened to your son and the amount of alcohol that he was forced to drink. And I just think it's so important that you continue to speak out as these other students head off. Do you think that Penn State has made meaningful change in terms the monitoring of these students and these frat houses?

PIAZZA: I think they've come a long way. I still think they have work to do. We are meeting with the president of Penn State in a couple of weeks to really get an understanding of what they've done so far and what they have ahead of them. We are actually going to be presenting at Penn State in a couple of weeks to a number of the Greek life folks.

(CROSSTALK)

MACCALLUM: That's wonderful.

PIAZZA: And we're hopeful that they'll see it all through.

MACCALLUM: That's good to hear. Before I let you go I know today is a big day of hope and a positive way forward for your family and you hope you will raise a lot of money for more scholarships, right?

PIAZZA: Yes, for scholarships and for those in need of prosthetics and mobility devices. And we had a great day. It rained a lot of course but we still had over 250 people come out and golf and 400 for dinner. And it's still going on right now and you can hear them at the background.

MACCALLUM: That's great. Well, we want you to get back to it but we know that Tim wanted to be an engineer and was very interested in prosthetics for children who can't afford them. And we've spoken to a family who benefitted from the great work you're doing earlier on the story. And we hope that you guys had a great night. Give our best to everyone. Thank you very much, Jim.

PIAZZA: Yes, they are here with us tonight. Thank you very much.

MACCALLUM: Good. I'm so glad. Take care. Jim piazza. Always good to see him.

So, coming up, more of The Story after this. Stay with us.

MACCALLUM: This August evening the president is about to get back to the White House. He just landed at Joint Base Andrews. And there he is. He was in Utica today signing the Defense Authorization bill. And we watch the president as he has been in Bedminster working for the past week and a half and so.

So that is our STORY on this Monday night. See you back here tomorrow night. "TUCKER" is up next.

Guy Reschenthaler (R-PA) is Interviewed about U.S. Embassy Clash; Recession Fears Rising; 2020 Tips to get Financially Fit; Apple Number One Dow Performer for the Entire Decade; Hackers Post Inappropriate Tweets about Rapper Eminem; 2019 Highest Box Office Totals Led by Disney Films2020-01-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:58ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTDanielle Hughes, Jack Brewer, Guy Reschenthaler, Sam Johnson, Jeremy Kaplan, Chris HoganNEWSFinancial010202cb.231Rep. Guy Reschenthaler (R-PA) is Interviewed about U.S. Embassy Clash; Recession Fears Rising; 2020 Tips to get Financially Fit; Apple Number One Dow Performer for the Entire Decade; Hackers Post Inappropriate Tweets about Rapper Eminem; 2019 Highest Box Office Totals Led by Disney FilmsLauren Simonetti, Liz Peek, Cheryl Casone

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN ANCHOR: January 2nd.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

Markets looking to keep the new year's celebration going. I should say the 2019 celebration going and welcome in the new year with a rally. The Dow up 149, the Nasdaq up 56.

Let's take a look at markets around the globe, rallying as well after China injects more liquidity into its banking system. The Shanghai composite higher.

This after a decade to remember. The Dow up over 173 percent. The S&P up nearly 190 percent. And the Nasdaq just shy of a 300 percent gain the past 10 years.

We're going to take a look at where opportunity lies in the new year.

The Europe, the year kicking off with a rally. The Euro Zone PMI for December showing manufacturing contracting for the 11th month in a row, but coming in better than expected. That helping to boost the markets. A 1.1 percent gain in France.

In Asia, solid gains on the Hang Seng despite violent new year's day protests in Hong Kong. China freeing up about $115 billion by cutting the amount of money banks must hold in reserves. The market loves it. The Shanghai composite gaining 1.1 percent. The Nikkei closed for a holiday.

A done deal. President Trump says phase one of the China trade deal will be signed on January 15th and he will be heading to Beijing to meet with President Xi as they work together on phase two.

Tensions with Iran. Protesters retreating after Iran-backed militias attacked the U.S. embassy in Baghdad. President Trump says he wants peace but warning that a war with Iran would not last long.

Plus, pizza anyone? Papa John's founder John Schnatter with a big new year's resolution, looking to beat his own record of 40 pizzas in 30 days. Why would you do that? Find out just how many pies he plans to consume this year.

And here with me to break it all down, pizza and all, Fox News contributor and columnist for "The Hill," Liz Peek, The Brewer Group's CEO, former investment banker and former NFL player, Jack Brewer, and Divine Asset Management's CEO Danielle Hughes.

Thanks' for joining us, guys.

DANIELLE HUGHES, CEO, DIVINE ASSET MANAGEMENT: Thanks for being here.

JACK BREWER, CEO, THE BREWER GROUP: Thank you (ph).

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Forty -- 40 pizzas in 30 days?

HUGHES: It just sounds gross (ph).

SIMONETTI: I know.

PEEK: Whoa.

BREWER: Sounds disgusting.

PEEK: Why not go for 60? I mean, really, you know.

SIMONETTI: I actually think that it sounds delicious.

BREWER: Oh.

SIMONETTI: Come on. Pizza is everything you need. It's healthy.

HUGHES: One piece.

SIMONETTI: A little bit.

BREWER: Until you digest it.

SIMONETTI: (INAUDIBLE).

Anyway, our top story this hour is not pizza, it is clashes at the U.S. embassy in Iraq and they are coming to an end.

Iran-backed military members, they retreated following two days of violent conflict at the American compound in Baghdad. The attack ended the aftermath prompting the Pentagon to send hundreds of additional troops to the Middle East.

Here's President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have some of our greatest warriors there. They got in there very quickly. As soon as we saw there was a potential for problems, they got in and there was no problem whatsoever.

I also want to thank the Iraqi government. They really stepped up. I spoke to the prime minister today. I thanked him. But they stepped up very nicely.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Joining me now, House Judiciary and Foreign Affairs Committee member and Iraq War veteran, Congressman Guy Reschenthaler.

Thank you so much, Congressman, for joining us. Happy New Year to you.

REP. GUY RESCHENTHALER (R-PA): Thanks for having me on. Happy New Year to you, too.

SIMONETTI: What are the president's red lines in the Middle East with Iran specifically?

RESCHENTHALER: Well, I think the big take-away is that if the president sets a red line, such as, do not attack U.S. bases or joint U.S. Iraqi bases, there will be consequences.
